awd_titl_txt: Predicting How Fluid-Solid Transitions in Cancer Tumors Help Govern Invasion and Metastasis
awd_abstract_narration:
Two important issues that arise in clinical treatment of carcinomas are 1) identification of tumor boundaries to guide surgical resection and 2) identification of biomarkers that accurately predict the invasiveness/aggressiveness of carcinomas in individual patients. The work in this proposal will address both of these issues using ideas that are different from yet complementary to ones currently being explored in cancer biology. Specifically, the PIs will identify the mechanical state of the tumor and use that information to quantify the mechanisms that are responsible for tissue cohesion and boundary maintenance. This will allow them to develop structural order parameters such as cell shape, tissue stiffness, or adhesion molecule expression that better delineate tissue boundaries for future use by pathologists or clinicians. The PIs will also test the conjecture that in combination with their theoretical framework, measurements of tissue fusion experiments or distributions of cell stiffness from primary tumor samples can serve as very accurate mechanical biomarkers for cancer aggressiveness. In addition, the proposed work will broaden participation in the interdisciplinary field of biophysics as the PIs will train a diverse group of undergraduate and graduate students and postdocs, as well as organize conferences and schools that provide professional development opportunities for a large number of young scientists. 

Although a physical barrier called the basement membrane initially encapsulates many primary tumors, tumor boundaries are often maintained even when cells break through that barrier. The mechanical and biochemical mechanisms that maintain and regulate these boundaries are poorly understood. Together, the PIs have very recently developed and experimentally verified a theoretical framework that for the first time explains fluid-to-solid transitions in confluent tissues, where there are no gaps between cells. There is mounting evidence that such transitions also occur in cancer tissues. Because fluid-like and solid-like tissues have different mechanisms for migration, self-organization, and cohesion, this proposal will augment and test a theoretical framework for jamming for cancer tissues and investigate how fluid-to-solid transitions affect tumor boundaries. In particular, the PIs will extend their framework to make testable, quantitative predictions for how cancer tissue boundaries evolve in different experimental geometries, and develop new theoretical techniques for predicting how mechanical heterogeneity can lead to rigidity percolation and self-organization of stream-like flows of soft cells. A second new technique will couple tissue models to extra-cellular matrix models to understand how the mechanical properties and motility modes of escaping cells are influenced by the mechanical properties of both the primary tumor and surrounding substrate.

por.por_cntn:
During the course of this award, the PIs contributed to a theoretical description of the mechanics of epithelial tissues (such as skin and lining of ducts in breast tissue) that serve as the point of origin of carcinomas, and launched new collaborations with biologists and biophysicists studying breast cancer and stratified epithelia to validate these theoretical predictions.

    Previous work had suggested that many tissues change their properties from fluid-like to solid-like, and that the fluidity of a cancer tissue may impact how easy it is for cells to escape from a tumor.  Therefore, one major area of focus was understanding how fluid-to-solid transitions can be identified in experimental data on tissues, catalyzed by our discovery that individual cell shapes correlate with tissue fluidity. To this end, we developed new techniques for extracting cell shapes from 3D images [Sharp et al PLOS ONE 2019] and developed an improved method that can predict tissue fluidity from cell shapes with no fit parameters [Wang et al PNAS 2020]. We also performed additional simulations to precisely characterize how tissue fluidity changes with active forces generated by cells [Sussman et al EPL 2018] and in the presence of active cell divisions [Czajkowski et al, Soft Matter 2019], which occur frequently in cancer tumors.

  Cancer tissues are also known to be composed of cells with heterogeneous mechanical properties. Therefore, a second area of focus was understanding how mixtures of two cell types interact, and whether the boundary between two cell types can act as a strong mechanical barrier that prevents cell escape.  We showed that when one cell type recognizes another cell type (called “heterotypic” interactions), a surprisingly strong barrier is formed [Sussman et al PRL 2018]. On the other hand, if one mixes two different cell types that are mechanically distinct, but one cell type does not recognize or respond to the other cell type, there is a very small barrier to cell escape. Moreover, we demonstrated that our predictions in this latter case were precisely realized in experiments on epithelial monolayers [Sahu, Sussman et al Soft Matter 2020]. We also showed that the mechanism that drives these surprising behaviors in confluent tissues (tissues with no gaps between cells) is quite general, and due to an unexpected decoupling between the tissue response to small perturbations compared to its response to large perturbations [Sahu, Kang et al Soft Matter 2020]. Ongoing work in collaboration with experimentalists seeks to understand the role of cell sorting in the 3D organization of stratified epithelia such as human skin, and how dysregulation of such sorting could enhance tumor formation.

   Finally, and perhaps most importantly, cancer tissues are known to be strongly influenced by their environment. Carcinomas are often surrounded by networks of extracellular matrix (ECM), and whether cells escape from the tumor is strongly dependent on the mechanical properties of the ECM and cell interactions with the ECM. Therefore, a third major focus of our grant was on predicting floppy-to-rigid transitions in the ECM [Merkel et al PNAS 2019] and how the boundary of spheroids (balls of cancerous confluent tissue) is affected by interactions with ECM. We developed a model for interactions between spheroids and ECM (which we think is the first of its kinds) and demonstrated that there are two regimes – one where the spheroid remains compact and more fluid-like, and another where the spheroid boundary becomes irregular and the tissue becomes more solid-like.  These regimes are controlled by the tension in the ECM network and the tension at the interface between the spheroid and ECM [Parker et al, arXiv:2006.16203  2020]. We are currently working with new experimental collaborators to test these predictions in cancer spheroids embedded in collagen networks.

In addition to broader impacts associated with specific research outcomes discussed above, this award contributed to broadening diversity in STEM disciplines. This award supported the training of two female physicists (women are significantly under-represented in physics)  – a postdoctoral associate and a graduate student. In addition, the PIs organized a conference for undergraduate women in physics (CUWiP) at Syracuse University with a theme of intersectionality in 2016, and in 2018 the PI organized a workshop and seed funding program for developing partnerships between minority-serving institutions and primarily white institutions. The PI also initiated and participated in partnerships involving training of junior undergraduate students from HBCUs Hampton University and North Carolina A&T.
